Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Peak \Peak\, v. i. [imp. & p. p. {Peaked}; p. pr. & vb. n. {Peaking}.] 1. To rise or extend into a peak or point; to form, or appear as, a peak. [1913 Webster]
There peaketh up a mighty high mount. --Holand. [1913 Webster]
2. To acquire sharpness of figure or features; hence, to look thin or sicky. ``Dwindle, peak, and pine.'' --Shak. [1913 Webster]
3. [Cf. {Peek}.] To pry; to peep slyly. --Shak. [1913 Webster]
{Peak arch} (Arch.), a pointed or Gothic arch. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Peaked \Peaked\, a. 1. Pointed; ending in a point; as, a peaked roof. [1913 Webster]
2. (Oftener ?) Sickly; not robust. [Colloq.] [1913 Webster]

peaked adj 1: somewhat ill or prone to illness; "my poor ailing grandmother"; "feeling a bit indisposed today"; "you look a little peaked"; "feeling poorly"; "a sickly child"; "is unwell and can't come to work" [syn: {ailing}, {indisposed}, {peaked(p)}, {poorly(p)}, {sickly}, {unwell}, {under the weather}] 2: having or rising to a peak; "the peaked ceiling"; "the island's peaked hills"
